awd_titl_txt: Developing Teaching Assistants' Pedagogical Knowledge of Inquiry Science Teaching & Instructional Leadership Skills, and Assessing the Impact on Student Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
To improve student learning in introductory college science lab courses, there is need for inquiry instruction that promotes coherent understanding and assessments that are aligned with the instruction. However, successful enactment of inquiry instruction in introductory college science lab courses requires teaching assistants' sound pedagogical knowledge for inquiry science teaching. Therefore, this research-based project is developing teaching assistants' pedagogical knowledge for teaching project-based guided inquiry science labs, and assessing the impact on student learning and attitudes towards science. The importance of this project is that it will provide research evidence on the development of teaching assistants' pedagogical knowledge of inquiry science teaching, resulting instructional practices, and the impact on student learning and attitude towards science, and subsequently increase student learning in science.

Many teaching assistants start teaching introductory college science labs without training in inquiry science teaching, yet the success of this instruction largely depends on the type of training they receive in inquiry science teaching. The goal of this project is to develop, implement and evaluate professional development training to develop teaching assistants' pedagogical knowledge for teaching project-based guided inquiry science labs and to assess the impact of the enhanced teaching on student learning and attitudes towards science. The project will employ a two-cohort cluster randomized trial with repeated measures design of pre- and post-measures, where introductory chemistry, physics and biology lab courses serve as the cluster level. Data will be collected through several instruments, including pre/posttests, interviews and observations protocols. A significant aspect of this project is that it will provide empirical evidence on how professional development training enhances teaching assistants' pedagogical knowledge for inquiry instruction, project-based guided inquiry lab development skills, inquiry instructional practices, and understanding of student engagement in science activities.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
This project developed, implemented, and  evaluated  a  transformative  professional development  (PD)  project  for  Teaching  Assistants  (TAs) of  the  introductory-level  Chemistry, Biology and Physics laboratory  courses. The project addressed the following objectives (1) develop project-based guided inquiry (PBGI) labs and assessments for introductory chemistry,  biology,  and  physics courses using  Knowledge  Integration  (KI) framework,  (2) develop TAs’ pedagogical knowledge for inquiry science instruction, inquiry laboratory development skills,  and  skills  for  student  engagement  in  science  activities,  (3)  implement  PBGI  labs  in introductory science lab courses, (4) measure the impact of the PD on TAs pedagogical knowledge for inquiry  science  instruction,  inquiry  instructional  practices, inquiry  lab development  skills,  and  understanding  of  student  engagement  in  science  activities,  (5)  measure  the effect of PBGI labs and TAs inquiry instruction practice on students’ learning in science labs, and attitude towards  science,  and   (6) provide  instructional  support  to  TAs  through  face-to-face  interactions  and online,  and  (7)  build  a  community of  practice  among  TAs  and  faculty  across  participant  science departments.  Data was collected using surveys, interviews, observations, and artifacts. The project developed and implemented  PBGI  labs. Seventy one (71) TAs in physics, chemistry and biology received training in inquiry lab instruction, and how to develop inquiry labs. They also taught inquiry science lab courses.  More than 5000 undergraduate students received instruction in PGBI labs over 3 years. Results show that TAs developed  positive conceptions of teaching science, pedagogical knowledge  for inquiry  instruction, skills for developing inquiry  labs,  and  understanding  of student  engagement  in  science  activities. TAs  improved  inquiry  instructional  practice   in  science labs.  Students improved learning  in  science labs,  and  developed positive perceptions of PBGI labs and attitude  towards  science. The intellectual merit is in the empirical  evidence  on  how  a  transformative  PD  enhanced  TAs’  pedagogical  knowledge  for  inquiry instruction, inquiry  lab development skills,  inquiry  instructional practices, and understanding of student engagement in science activities. The broader impacts include the development of PBGI labs  the departments are using in laboratory courses. Addtionally, TAs’ pedagogical knowledge of inquiry-based instruction has impacted on their skills for developing and teaching inquiry science labs, which will result into increased student learning. PBGI labs are available for  other  institutions  to  use.   This PD model for addressing inquiry instruction in undergraduate science lab courses is transferable to other institutions. Overall, the project  improved  student learning outcomes and TAs’ conceptions of science teaching, inquiry instruction  practice, and inquiry lab development skills.
